comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I think it is not the 'Marksworth' but the 'MERKSWORTH' a coastal trader (not a tug). It had a collision with the ferry 'Manly' off Bradleys Head on 18/12/1896. Adelaide Advertiser 23/12/1896 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/34568675 (the best of several contemporary newspaper articles). Hence repairs in dry dock (Sutherland Dock?). The 'Merksworth' was wrecked in 1898 off Stockton Beach - SMH 17/05/1898 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14147287

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Good to see you travelling around with the same wealth of detail and eye for a good shot.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Ha! Fancy seeing you here swordscookie! Yes, I am all over these Australian 'mystery' photos like a rash, and need to get a life. They are almost laughably easy to find out about due to trove.nla.gov.au/ . The contemporary newspaper reports really give an extra dimension, or two. .

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thank you again beachcomberaustralia for your tireless research. Trove is a fantastic resource and certainly does add a dimension to the photographs we may not have otherwise realised.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
